content.description:
Possibly the best boulder problem in the June Lake area, pretty much perfect in every way. Stand start at a hueco at the lip of the roof, using an interior pocket for the right hand and edge of the hueco for left. Pull on and get a heel, reach to the arete and climb up some big holds. Get established on incut edges then traverse left onto the face, finishing up somewhat boldly on decent pockets and edges.

The high jump start to jugs on the arete is supposedly V4. The low start in the back of the cave is "The End of the Road" V12.
content.location: North side of the boulder, the path of least resistance.

content.description: Another superb line, this climbs straight up the middle of the north face. Begin hanging from an overhead hueco under the lip of the roof (right next to the supporting boulder). Make a fun first move campusing to a good hold up and right, then throw a heel on and continue straight up. Crank past some thin shallow slots and then finish out the same last couple moves of The Road.

Climbs up the black streak to the right of Bachar Ladder. Great climbing over a not so great landing. But with a few pads it can be made reasonably safe to fall.

Stand start with a right hand crimp and left hand sloper. Sustained moves on small pockets and edges head straight up to the notch.

There is also a low start at V10.

This is basically an alternate start to Last Man Standing. Start on the same hueco as The Road and traverse left along the lip of the roof on big holds. Once you reach the start of Last Man Standing, finish straight up that line. Steep and juggy for the first half, thin and vertical for the second half, awesome climbing throughout.

The Countdown avoids the first powerful campus move of LMS, but requires several more moves of steep climbing which adds a bit of pump, making the crux thin pulls feel slightly harder when you get to them. Probably a little easy for a V9 though.

You can also start sitting in the back of the cave and climb the hard compression moves of "The End of the Road" and link all that into LMS. This is called The Final Countdown (V12), and might still be the hardest established problem at Hartley.

If this had a good landing it would maybe be even better than The Road. Awesome climbing on perfect rock.

Start standing at the same hueco as The Road, with an interior undercling pocket for the right hand. Do the same first few moves getting established on the arete, then split off right to a couple big crimps. Continue up and right along the overhanging west face of the boulder past two powerful reaches. At the lip, mantle over to the right.

It's got really big holds the whole way, so if you're strong enough it can feel really secure and easy. You can also step off onto the boulder behind you at any point, so you can work the moves without fear of becoming committed. However an uncontrolled fall could possibly be very unpleasant, and it can get pumpy by the end, so don't take it too lightly.
